I advise the BerkShares program in the Berkshires. It started as a local paper currency in 2006 and has been digitized in the last year (with an app and Celo smart contract).

We're actually looking for a software engineer to run the digital program...

https://www.berkshares.org

The Schumacher Center hires staff to do outreach for the BerkShares program, and they have a bunch of local currency resources on their website, including a directory of projects https://centerforneweconomics.org/apply/local-currencies-program/

Past timestamps are unreliable, so a bad actor can get around the "valid until" cut-off by submitting new messages with old timestamps. Hubs can reject messages with future timestamps, but we can't (currently) validate that a given message was actually posted at some point in the past like a blockchain would.
👌 made the same thing a couple nights ago

Yeah, there's probably something we can do longer term with snapshot consensus, though that increases sync complexity and is less important in a world of ephemeral data. See the pruned sets doc here: https://hackmd.io/@farcasterxyz/BJj3zuVVj

Agreed. The only recourse is to re-sign the messages you want to retain using another key. There's a similar problem when an fid is transferred from one custody address to another, which we've discussed here if you're interested: https://hackmd.io/@farcasterxyz/B1gcCwESj

We decided to rename it a couple weeks ago, because we wanted to differentiate the concept of a farcaster hub from the first typescript hub implementation. 

And “hubble” beat out “tub” for better or for worse.
This is good https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/10/opinion/ezra-klein-podcast-rick-rubin.html
The problem has to do with ordering. For registrations, we care about who was first. But for reactions (and most data on hubs), we care about the most recent state (who was last).
A blockchain is good for the first case, because (in exchange for a performance hit) you can prove that something occurred at a specific time in the past.

Farcaster CRDTs are good for the second case, because while we can't validate that something actually occurred when you say it did, hubs are very fast and can block messages that claim to be from the future.
Unfortunately, yeah
Red Hook, NY (Hudson Valley not Brooklyn)
Happy to answer questions about hubble or give suggestions if that would be helpful. You can get pretty far using the subscribe hub method right now to listen to events.
This would be neat

I would recommend using the gRPC methods to interact with the hub—and specifically the subscribe method to get all relevant events. I'd imagine you'd have to write a lot of extra code to interact with rocksdb and decode keys and values correctly.
Yeah, using /js and that method is going to be the easiest approach in nodejs. We haven't (yet) published a similar package for using gRPC in browsers though.

If you're using something other than javascript, you can generate a gRPC client using your favorite protocol buffers library using the schema here: https://github.com/farcasterxyz/hubble/blob/d7c9e0a4ab26156a7fc9c3542eff1dd94d457d99/packages/protobufs/src/schemas/rpc.proto

Who is building etherscan for farcaster hubs? I want to specify a hub endpoint and an fid and see all the data the hub has plus a list of all hub events involving that fid. I have a bunch of scripts to do this locally, but a ui would be nice, especially for handling pagination and fids with lots of data.
Oh great, when can I try?

Some specific use cases to consider:
- Run same query (i.e. getAllSignerMessagesByFid) across multiple hubs
- Search event history (especially revoke or prune events)
Nice, excited to try. Ideally, I'd be able to easily switch between hub endpoints to check the state and events on each one, though I imagine that may not be relevant for most users.
